plist.p: Okay. [Foreign Language] (00:20) Just trying to confirm that the connection is on. Yeah, okay, fine, great. Well, so we'll start. Good morning to you all. This is Pierre-André Terisse speaking from – Danone's CFO. I'm here with Antoine Guttinger, Investor Relation, and Lambert Deloche de Noyelle. We're very glad to be in London today for this meeting.

A year ago, at the same event (00:48) or host the event in Paris, given the proximity of the Olympic Games, sorry. We finally got of the opinion that it was important to come and see you here. We accepted the invitation from Nomura, and they should be thanked for that and for hosting the call. I want to thank you, the people in this room, personally for having made the effort to come today. I know, again, given the Olympic Games, it's not so easy to come. And I want to welcome as well the people who are on the line.

Now, this word of introduction being made, I'd like to say that I'm very glad to report a solid set of results for the first half, which are in line with our objective for H1 and Q2 despite a combination of factors, more or less predictable, from high comps in Water to the carryover effects of the inflation of the first half of last year from the poor weather conditions in Europe in the second quarter to the worsening consumption trends in Southern Europe in April. Over the first half, there's been a number of takeaways for us, the management of the group, and I would like to share two or three of them with you.

First, I think we should not forget that we have a very good set of brands and business all over the world which account for two-thirds of the group and grow more than 10% in average. These are: Mizone, Dumex, Aqua, (2:32), Danone-Unimilk, Oikos, Danone Japan, South Africa, Brazil, Al Safi Danone in Saudi Arabia, Bonafont (2:44) and actually all of our operations outside Western Europe.

They do deliver profitable growth quarters-after-quarters in dairy, in waters, in baby and in medical nutrition. These are the engines of the group, and all we need to do is to keep shooting them and growing them again and again. And their potential is I believe huge, probably one of the best potential in this industry, in the food industry, outside Europe.

In front of that, we have obviously one-third of all sales in Western Europe, North and South. This part of the business has progressively started growing. Consumption trends in Southern Europe have even it embodied in negative to treaties since the beginning of the year. This is something we have even brought it in negative territory since the beginning of the year. This is something we have to manage and handle proactively by addressing our portfolio and pricing terms, by addressing it as well in terms of offer, by adjusting our costs; not using either of these levers but using them all at the same time. We are now three months after the end of April. We know that in Southern Europe it's not going to be easy. We know it will take time and we think it will be definitely the right decision to adjust sooner targets for the year.

About Europe, we feel like we felt three years ago about waters. We feel this determined (4:00) and pressure that will get stronger out of this situation. So this is a group, a combination of a very strong non-European business with a huge potential for growth and, again, probably without equivalents in the industry. And, at the same time, a European business which sells to consumers under pressure and which we need to manage. We feel ready to handle those successfully and this is what I wanted to tell you as an introduction.

Now, after these remarks, let me run you through the first half results in more detail. So, I'll go through the highlights of the first half to start with, starting with page four. Sales growth from the first half has been 5.9% with a strong Q1 at 6.9%, and logically a softer Q2 at 5% on a high comparison basis.

Trading operating margin has stood at 13.85%, down by 61 basis points like-for-like on Southern Europe and pressure of raw material. Free cash flow at last has reached €890 million, reflecting a strong cash flow generation, but also a different CapEx phasing from last year, with €90 million more CapEx this first half than there was a year ago.

If I look at our environment, and you know this slide which we've been using now for the past few quarters., we've seen basically three things throughout the first half. A, an inflation which has been a little bit higher than what we expected, notably on some specific raw material which has been the whey and the milk proteins, and we have tried in front of that to generate more productivity to increase our level of productivity.

On the consumer side, we've seen in Southern Europe, which has been deteriorating steeply in the second quarter. I'll come back on that, requiring adjustments and also specific report (6:23). In the rest of the world and in emerging markets, on the contrary, we have seen a demand which has continued to stay strong, and we've seen our business keeping growing shares and keeping – sorry, keeping growing sales and profitability and keeping doing what they're supposed to do which is to build and develop their category in these markets.

So these dual trends are basically moving the group or keep moving the group. As you can see on the chart, with sales and margins up, growth markets now represent about two-thirds of our sales, and they've increased their relative size by 3 points, while Western Europe has, on the contrary, decreased by 3 points versus the first half of last year.

About Western Europe, a word on Spain. What we have seen in the first part of the second quarter has basically been confirmed by what we have seen in the rest of the quarter. Consumer confidence which had dropped in the first – at the beginning of Q2, has basically remained at about the same level, which means 50%, as you can see on the chart. And with respect to sales, we have seen a negative mid-single digit evolution of our sales in April. We have seen that continuing throughout the quarter, and we do not expect that the situation is going to improve in any shape or form over the rest of the year. So this is what we assume when we look at the rest of the year.

We've already started managing the situation, as you can imagine, using different levers. I'm not going to come back into a lot of details on that. I just would like to mention two things. One is Yolado, which for the moment is a real small innovation, but which looks very promising. Yolado is a yogurt which you put in your freezer at home and which you eat frozen. This is a very good one – sorry, a very good product. We have completely saturated the line almost immediately. We are now looking at building additional capacity. But this can be, among other things, a solution and innovation which can be useful to Spain.

Secondly, I will mention that we have finalized throughout the quarter the work we have started at the beginning, which consists in moving old (9:00) price points. We have in our portfolio to understand where the elasticity stands. We have this work which is being done and we'll now be ready to be more efficient in the way we use the pricing tool to meet consumer demand.

Last, we are pushing on productivity and, in particular, through a new project called Cost Or Valuing(9:26), which is going to be throughout the organization consisting in trying to find value for – more value for the consumer or decreased costs. These are examples of the levers are going to be implemented. They are progressively being activated, and they will be activated pragmatically to manage the situation.

Outside Western Europe, as I said, we're talking of double-digit growth as an average. And in total I would just like on this call to mention the performance of few of our brands. Prostokvashino, growth of 11%. Oikos, and we'll see that later on, has doubled its sales versus last year. Mizone is still going at a pace north of 40%. Dumex is going at a pace which is north of 15%. So brands which keep adding attraction, which is absolutely strong and helping the development of our sales and of our categories in all these markets.

This is the situation today. We keep expanding and trying to address new geographies. I will mention two. Just as a reminder, you know – you remember that we have announced this half that we've acquired 38% of Centrale Laitière au Maroc, which, on top of the existing stake we had in it, is going to give us a majority now as to consolidate and get the management directly of this operation from presumably the beginning of next year of the end of this year. That's going to add €600 million sales to our portfolio with a fairly good level of EBIT margin and potential improvement which are significant. Strong brand platform which we think we have the ability to keep developing further and which, by the way, is going to be useful in thinking about our African strategy.

Second, India. It took us a bit of time but we closed this transaction yesterday, a transaction which was announced 11 months ago actually. It's taken time, as it often takes in this kind of – in this particular geography. But it's done. In the meantime, the asset has performed very well, plus 22% of sales in the first half. And, therefore, we are getting a healthy business, which, again, is going to be a very useful platform for Baby and Medical, which, as you know, are two of the most dynamic of our businesses.

I would just like to say a word, before moving into the figures more in detail, about sustainability. It remains a very, very important axis of development for Danone because it guarantees that we'll be able to deliver growth, not only in the short term but also in the medium term. Two examples, we've been entering the Top 10 of the Best Global Green Brands in 2012 recently; we actually rank 9. And this means the efforts we are doing in terms of environmental protection are being perceived and recognized by the consumer. And, secondly, we are progressively rolling out the SAP platform for carbon footprint measurement. And, for that, we've received a reward here in the UK, which is (13:04-13:08) given by Finance for the Future. So that's one.

On the left hand side of the presentation you will see sourcing. As part of our management in Russia and the effort for making the business sustainable for Danone and its environment, we've set up a Milk Business Academy around a farm which is going to receive in the next five years, 700 farmers, train them, with a very concrete goal which aims at increasing in the yield of the farm and the yield of the milk of cows 10%, and ensuring high-quality and long-term supply of milk for them. So, this is the group and this is what I wanted to say about the various events which have been taking place throughout the first half. I'll now go into more figures on this.

Key figures, I'm not going to go through everything again, just to mention that for the first time time, I think in the history of the group we have a first half – or a half, simply, which is in excess of €10 billion. So that shows that through acquisition of these but also organically, we are actually growing and going through our milestones. 5.9% like-for-like, so that it right in the middle of the guidance for the half, with a rebalancing between Q1 and Q2, as you know. Operating margin down by 61 basis points like-for-like, 62 basis points reported. And EPS which is up by almost 5 points at €1.51, and a cash flow, again, which is down on higher CapEx on the different phasing.

About the sales, two things to mention here. 7.7% reported, that comes from the fact that we had a currency affect of 2 points over the first half, no scope effects. And the 5.9% is broken down into 2.2% and 3.7%. Interestingly, this breakdown gives the same result in terms of volume for the second quarter, 2.1%, but that is obviously down at different things. In particular, Water is obviously down given the weather condition in the second quarter, while Baby is up by about the same amount or even more. Value is decreasing as we move into the anniversary of price increase which we passed for the majority of them in the first half of last year. And the currency effect, as you can see, is slightly higher in the second quarter than it is for the half.

If you look at the dynamics of that again, 7% in Q1 was very much at the top of the guidance of the 5% to 7% guidance. 5% is at the bottom. I would just like to remind you that we had a second quarter last year which was exceptional in Water for two reasons. Number one, because of Japan and the loading of inventory in these countries following the catastrophe of tsunami and Fukushima, and, secondly, because we had tremendously good weather conditions in April and May in Europe. In front of that, we've obviously had very bad weather conditions and, therefore, we are where we thought we would be some time ago – sorry, a month ago or two months ago, which is at 5% for Q2. And, again, that reflects the dual feature of Western Europe sales which are declining and the rest of the world, which is growing double digits.

Volume value, you'll find what I mentioned before, i.e., the decrease of the value effects since the 2011 price increase are lapsing gradually. And on the contrary, volumes which stay stable with aggressive contribution from Baby and lot of contribution of Water.

And now moving to the performance of each of the divisions. I'll start with Dairy. At Q2, which I think can be qualified as soft, at 2.1% and 2.9% for the first half, Q2 is softer than Q1 for two reasons, number one, because we had the Leap Day more in Q1 and, secondly, because of the deterioration in Southern Europe and Spain, which you saw before.

CIS and North America are definitely on track, I will come back on that. Latin America has been providing very solid performance, in particular in Brazil, and we will be needing to add capacity in these countries very soon. Danone South Africa has been delivering as well a very good performance with, in particular the brand Mayo, which is successful. And Indonesia with Milkuat has been confirming the take-off which we have seen from last year.

Volume unchanged, with CIS contributing so I'm pleased (18:32) this is the first quarter, while Spain has been obviously contributing negatively to the evolution and, therefore, we're at minus 0.3 versus minus 0.1, the value effect reflects, as I said, the lapsing of the 2011 price increase.

One word about the CIS and Unimilk. I think you can see on the right hand side of the screen, the progress we've made. This is showing the volumes, this shows that we had a very debalanced evolution of sales last year with very negative volumes for the restructuring of the portfolio and the price increase and, at the same time, very positive value effects. We have a much more balanced relative goals this year, which is positive in volume, positive in value, and, as a result, of course, positive in sales, and which is showing gradual acceleration. What we are building is very solid.

On the left hand side, it's probably even more satisfactory to see it. We are building this growth food brands – we are building this growth through Prostokvashino, which is really, I'll come back on that, making progresses. We are building this (19:50), with Activia, with Actimel. And therefore, we are really on track on with the plan, which I remind you, consisted in building brand equity and building a portfolio which will be much more resilient than the previous one. This is what we're in the process of doing.

You'll see that actually on Prostokvashino, this is a small cat, very traditional, very close to the families in the Russian image. We have renovated and strengthened the brand and that's given remarkable performance, with 11% like-for-like sales in the first half. We'll keep renovating the brands one after the other and building the support to build up the sales.

So this is Russia, it's really one of the markets we are investing significantly to build up and to take – I'm sorry, to build the category. The U.S. is the other one. I think we can say that the U.S. has been a very good performer for Danone Dairy in the first half and in the second quarter particularly. The brand Oikos has become a clear number two, taking 7.3% share of market, about 20% – more than 20% actually, share of the segment, multiplying sales by more than two. And this has helped Danone to become now the clear market leader, with 33%, ahead of all of its competitors. This performance is in line with our targets. And, of course, the second half which is coming is going to be even more important, given that would be adding capacity.

About what's coming, we will not only be adding capacity we'll as well as some of our competitors are doing, we'll be going with new references. We are going to move on multipack for Oikos, which is an important one. We have decided to combine our legitimacy in knowing how to do and process Greek yogurt with the legitimacy of the brand Light & Fit on the light to produce a Greek yogurt which is going to be not 100 calories, but 80 calories. And we think that could be successful. We are going to launch a new Activia Breakfast, and we have opened on Park Avenue in New York a yogurt company a kind of a space which is going to be open for people to try and discover and understand fermented products and yogurt.

We're not only moving in the U.S., we're moving outside as well. Oikos, as I mentioned, has received this first half the Best New Product Award in Canada. As you can see, we have launched a light version of Griego in Spain, and here in the UK we've launched a version of Oikos with wine, (22:45) which I encourage you to taste because I can tell you it's really very, very, very good.

Yolado, I mentioned that it's been extremely well received and now the question is going to be about adding capacity and looking at what we can do on that after, obviously, confirming that there is significant potential. So this was about Dairy and a soft Q1 but a lot of promises and initiative in two key markets, U.S. and Russia, which are doing extremely well.

Waters, a soft Q2 and, after all, not such a soft Q2 because delivering a 4.6% with all the conditions I've mentioned is probably the sign of very, very resilient division now. So as strong H1 growth altogether, first of all, close to 10%, 9.6%. Q2 which has been hit by the element I already mentioned to you, i.e., the comps and the weather, we continue seeing strong underlying category dynamics and we continue benefiting from the outperformance of the Aquadrinks. I've mentioned the performance of Mizone, this is true as well in other markets, in Argentina for instance and in particular.

In terms of the volume value equation, really shows and illustrates what I said about the strength of the model. A few years ago, all the factors combined would have given a very negative geographical mix which would have brought value in negative. We know that in front of that, the addition of positive mix coming from the Aquadrinks, and that's helping to add the value element, which remains positive at 1.5%. The 3.1% of volume is in line with the previous quarter, a bit lighter on the comps and as well on a slightly softer Q2 in Mexico.
(25:02) Slide 24. Just a minute, please.

Thank you. (25:35) Okay. So for everybody here in the room and those on the call, I understand the call has been cut, page 24. So I will just start again, page 24. Forgive me for who has heard the pages are ready. I was saying, page 24, that the U.S. has been performing very well in the second quarter and in the first half altogether. Oikos is doubling its sales, taking 7.3% share of market of the total category, more than 20% share of segment of the Greek. And that's been helping Danone to become a clear leader on the market with 33%. And a performance which is in line with our targets, knowing that H2 is going to be obviously an important time for Oikos in the U.S.

We are launching several products, a multipack version of Oikos. A Light & Fit version, of Oikos, a lightened version, combining our know-how in Greek and position of the brand with 80 calories. An Activia Breakfast version, and we have opened a new shop on Central – on Park Avenue, sorry, in New York, which is about yogurt and I think is going to be the opportunity for American consumers to discover this category and enter in it.

More innovation in Dairy, I'll go quickly. But Canada, we've received the award for the best product in the first half with Oikos and we are launching Oikos as well here in the UK. I think it's already launched. Yolado in Spain, I already mentioned, that could be a promising start. We need to confirm, but that's, I think, something which can help revitalize the category in Western Europe.

So about – I'm moving to Water. Sorry. I'm actually moving back. And I was – yeah, just a comment that 4.6% in Q2 is a real good and solid performance, given the weather conditions and the high comps. This is confirming that we are in a category with very strong dynamics. Solid in Western Europe, very strong outside, and we are benefiting as well from Aquadrinks, which are always very strong.

And if I look at the breakdown of that, the 1.5% in value to me is very important because it is the combination of a very positive mix coming from the Aquadrinks and a very negative, obviously, geographical mix given the performance of Europe this quarter, but it means that the model is more resilient than it used to be in the past.

And in Water as well, we try to innovate in Evian the city – the Evian Masters, the golf championship has become a major so that's going to add to the image of the brand, which is obviously very important. We are launching a sparkling version of Volvic in Germany in order to strengthen our position in this segment or the category in which we had mainly Badoit and Salvetat previously, so French brands.

Baby nutrition, I think it's – we can qualify that as an outstanding performance, even more so when you take away the exceptional elements coming from the renovation of Dumex and reloading – the loading of the distribution, which accounts for 1 point to 2 points out of the 13.6%. The rest is all organic performance on all of the same very good drivers, i.e., milk performing well when food is declining, and in milk all the countries are growing. This is a case of the UK for instance, high-single digit. This is the case of most European countries, and this the case even more so in Asia and, in particular, in China where we have been regaining some market share.

So we keep as well innovating in this area. Two things, the renovation of Dumex, which, as I said, is important. We are bringing additional qualities, additional elements to the formula and we think that's going to strengthen a brand which is already very strong on the Chinese market. This is in process of being done.

And on the food side, we are taking what I believe could be an important step, i.e., we are launching Blédina du Jour. Blédina du Jour is the fresh version of the jars, which if you happen to go to France and see this, then I encourage you to taste for yourself. I've done it. It's very good, even for adults. This is put in a fridge which is in the baby aisle. And I think that's going to be a very attractive proposition for the consumer and help us, again, making this product category take off.

Medical Nutrition, our trends which are very similar to Q1 with the same detail, i.e., overall performance which is very good, overall Western Europe which is resisting (31:08) well. This is a case of the UK for instance, which, as you know, is one of – the most important business we have in Medical Nutrition. Southern Europe is definitely a drag and, at the same time, we have seen the U.S. becoming more competitive. That was already the case in Q1 and it's confirmed in Q2.

Emerging markets go up strongly. That's the case in particular, China and Russia. One of the important elements of the year is the progress we are doing on Souvenaid. We've seen a very interesting publication in The Journal of Alzheimer's Disease in the issue of July 2012. We'll be attending a conference, which is the Alzheimer's Association International Conference in Vancouver I believe – yeah, in Vancouver, later this year. And we are preparing the launch of these products in several countries towards the end of the year, beginning of next.

So all that is obviously doing a geographical map – a geographical breakdown of sales which is dual, as we said in the heading of the slides, minus 1% in Europe. And this is with Unimilk, which is contributing positively and, therefore, ex-Unimilk, that minus 1% will become minus 2.5% approximately.

Asia remains very strong, with Japan negative effect versus last year. And, therefore, at plus 17% that's a very, very good performance. And the rest of the world is very strong, with Mexico, which has been a bit softer this quarter, consensually, (32:50) and the rest of the countries remaining very strong, including the good performance of the U.S.

I'll now move to the margin. The left column, which is the reported one, is here to remind you that we, in the 2011 accounts, we changed the way we account for pensions. And we add an adjustment which was already presented in the full year 2011. It's obviously impacting the basis of the comparison for these results and, therefore, we are not starting from the 14.35% margin, but we are starting from the 14.47% margin.

In front of that, we are delivering 13.85%. This is made of €1.451 billion trading operating income and €40 million non-operating or other operating items and current items which are predominantly the integration costs of Unimilk. The margin is, therefore, down 62 basis points and, out of the 62 basis points, 61 basis points like-for-like. There is 1 basis point for the scope and currency effect all together.

What you see on this chart is that most of the evolution of the margin and drop of the margin has been coming from input costs and inflation more generally, which has been reaching to 249 bps and has not been fully offset by pricing. This is very much a carryover effect of the fact that the input costs have been increased throughout the first half of last year and, therefore, we had a base of comparison which was low. When you will see this picture in the second half, definitely the impact of the inflation will not be at all at this magnitude. But, conversely, what you can see on the leverage, which is negative, this is reflecting the deterioration of the situation in Southern Europe and, therefore, it extends to negative. This is the impact of one quarter; we'll have twice this impact in the second quarter.

So, margin down by 61 bps on a like-for-like basis. Again, talking about inflation, I'm just going to repeat what we said earlier this year. Specific inflation on three – higher inflation than expected on specific things, in particular the first cartridge (35:19) whey and milk protein, which have been growing in excess of 20%. Overall, this means that inflation for the first half has been higher than the one we expected. And we expect for the full year that it's going to be slightly in excess of what we expect, although we expect as well that in the second half things are going to stop growing. In front of that productivity, we are definitely targeting an improvement in excess of €500 million, and we have been producing a significant part of that in the first half, with €246 million.

Turning to top line, different levers. One is A&P which we keep stable with the A slightly up and the P slightly down versus last year. A significant increase of the proportion of digital media spend within the A&P. A global agreement with Google which aims at three priorities: optimize the media mix for digital, innovate and build digital capabilities. Our joint missions to build leverage together, a digital advantage for both Danone and Google.

Apart from A&P, obviously, we have other levers which are equally important. R&D is one of them. Sales force is another one of them, very important indicator for Baby and Medical. And these two levers have been growing double digits. So we keep, obviously, putting fuel in efforts where we need them to keep growing our categories.

Looking at the margins by business and by geography, no surprise, this reflects pretty much what I've shown you in terms of evolution of sales and what I've said so far about the reason or the drivers of the margin change. Dairy, that's minus 85 bps, impacted by Southern Europe and the carryover of inflation of milk, in particular. Waters is as well impacted by the carryover inflation, while weather conditions in Europe have not helped the solid performance of the first half.

Baby is in a clear investment mode and, at the same time, have been seeing their costs increasing from the whey. But they're clearly investing and trying to accelerate the building of their category. Medical Nutrition has been impacted by Southern Europe. And if you look at it geographically, unsurprisingly, Europe is negative 200 bps. What's impressive is the performance of Asia, which goes from 20.6% to 22.6%, and this is very much the result of the performance of Dumex and Mizone, which are doing very well. Rest of the world as well is delivering a very solid margin growth, with 36 bps from 12% to 12.36% over the first half.

Sorry. I'm moving from the operating income to net income. Financial expenses have been up on the cost of hedging, which has increased over the first half from €133 million to €138 million. Affiliates has been up as well on the Asia and North Africa result, which, I remind you, had been very low last year – in the first half of last year and, therefore, benefit from a low comparison base. This explains the move from €23 million to €39 million. On the minority side, you have two movements which are quite basically Russian is increasing and Spanish are decreasing for minorities, which remain stable. Altogether, the underlying net income is up by 4%.

Income tax, there's obviously some pressure in France but also outside, with an increasing cost of moving money from one country to the other. In France, what we have seen so far is unlikely to have significant impact in 2012 and, therefore, we think we'll be in our 26% to 27% guidance on the rest of the year. Obviously, we'd have to take into account what it is going to be discussed and voted later this year.

All that gives an EPS, which, on the base of fully-diluted number of shares decreasing from 606 million to 603 million, is increasing by 4.7%, from €1.44 to €1.51 per share. And schematically, that is a 5% increase, which can be broken down into two parts. One is currency and scope, explaining about half of it. 2.1% in currency, which is very much the reflection of what we have seen on the stairs (40:35) in particular. And 2.5% like-for-like growth, which, again, if you try to understand schematically is going to be, 6% top line (40:45) translation of minus 61 bps is minus 4%, roughly speaking. And, therefore, you get 2 points of EPS progression, plus 0.5 being the net of tax, financial charges and the rest. So 6% minus 4% plus 0.5 gives you 2.5% for the first half.

In terms of cash, I'm not going to stay on this slide, rather go on the other. Free cash flow this first half has been €890 million. Again, that's down since the first half of last year which was €925 million, so it's down €35 million, principally attributable to CapEx which we have decided to phase in the first half a little bit more than last year, at €415 million, and with a working capital which remains – keeps doing a lot of progress, going from €958 million and 5.2% of sales a year ago to in excess of €1 billion and 5.8% for the first time for 2012. So, still very sound cash flow dynamics.

This cash has been used to pay dividends essentially, €890 million, dividends, €1 billion, which means that the debt has increased in the first half, which is very traditional and normal in our case, by €166 million. Out of the €1 billion dividends of course, €830 million, I believe, has been paid to the main shareholders and the rest has been paid to minority shareholders. So €166 million brings the debt to €6.8 billion, which is down versus a year ago. Our balance sheet, on the other hand, is up by 4%, reflecting a growth which is larger than the growth of our sales all together and including the ForEx effect.

Two elements of the balance sheet, just one quick short about the debt to remind you that we have launched a U.S. bond issue in U.S. dollars in the first half, which basically allows us to diversify further on that and we've made a coupon of 3% over 10 years. So I believe that's all good in terms of managing, of course, the financing of the group. We have, obviously, a maturity profile which is absolutely safe.

And, secondly, the transaction we've made with minority shareholders on which of Danone's -sorry, on which I'm going to spend a bit of time just to explain. So you all know that we have, as part of the debt of the group, as part of the €6.8 billion, an amount of put option which is approximately €3.5 billion. Out of this €3.5 billion, €2.2 billion, €2.153 exactly, correspond to the debt – the put option, sorry, owed to the minority shareholders of Danone Spain.

We have concluded the transaction with two of these minority shareholders by which we are going to buy from them their shares, moving, therefore, from 58% of Danone Spain to 67%, and we're going to pay that in cash purpose, €91 million of cash, and in treasury stock for the rest, which is €6 million, or 110,039 shares of Danone. Now, two things about that. The first is that's immediately, and when I say immediately this is in coming weeks, we are going to buy back these shares so as to neutralize the impact of the transaction and, therefore, that would be as a result paid in debt. The second thing is that if you calculate €91.5 million cash and (45:00) at yesterday's stock price of 6 million treasury stock, you get to an amount of €380 million, which means that we have paid €380 million for cancelling a debt which was valued in our balance sheet at €460 million.
